title: typewriter like font
author: bardia

comments.content:
In 1935 a New York hospital would have most probably have used typewriters from US companies such as Underwood, Remington, Smith Premier etc.  
At the scale of your image I can't tell you the make or model used.

Details of typefaces used by these and other companies changed over the years. Some key letters to check are \_4\_, whether open or closed -- your sample is closed and \_3\_ -- whether round top or flat top -- your sample is flat top. Also whether the \_g\_ is one story, i.e. with a tail like a hook or two story, i.e. with a closed bowl at the bottom, like a pair of glasses -- your sample is two story. There are other features of your sample that you could seek to duplicate, like the ball at the end of the tail at the top of \_6\_, but most people would not notice this.

If you want to duplicate the feel of a typewriter you need a monospaced font. If the font does not say then check the sample text \_NMW\_ or \_nmw\_. The \_M\_ and \_W\_ should look squeezed so that the type key width is the same as \_N\_. All keys are the same width, so in a monospace typewriter font the \_I\_ and \_i\_ usually have very wide serifs to fill the space.

Some monospace fonts that would work as substitutes:  
LTC Remington Typewriter, [no obvious discrepancies, a fairly high probability that this was the make used, & very cleanly engineered font] [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-remington-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-remington-typewriter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lanston/ltc-remington-typewriter/") Includes an italic designed by Frederic Goudy in 1927.  
Remington Elite [wrong \_3\_, but a fairly high probability that this was the make used, & very cleanly engineered font]  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/remington-elite-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/remington-elite-typewriter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/remington-elite-typewriter/")  
Underwood Typewriter [no obvious discrepancies, a fairly high probability that this was the make used, & very cleanly engineered font]  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/underwood-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/underwood-typewriter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/underwood-typewriter/") also [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/underwood-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/underwood-typewriter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/underwood-typewriter/")  
Smith Premier NF [no obvious discrepancies & very cleanly engineered font]  
Intellecta Typewriter [no obvious discrepancies]  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/intellecta-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/intellecta-typewriter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/intellecta/intellecta-typewriter/")  
Bulletin Typewriter [no obvious discrepancies]  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/bulletin-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/bulletin-typewriter/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/itfmecanorma/bulletin-typewriter/")

If you do not need a monospace font a good generic substitute is ITC American Typewriter [https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-american-typewriter/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/https:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-american-typewriter/ "https://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-american-typewriter/")

I did not include grunge or distressed faces. IMHO they are a waste of time for recreating documents.

Update:  
Deleted possibly controversial comment.

Update:  
I don't know if these otf fonts can be used on a Mac. If not there is always Courier,despite the one story \_g\_.  
Don

So is Frank Spano a notorious gangster? His occupation -- hand written, not typed -- is "ice dealer." I've heard of "putting someone on ice" as an euphemism for killing them...  
There is a role playing game, Speakeasy Dollhouse, that includes the comment "a speakeasy owner named Frank Spano, was shot."  
---game explanation quote---  
The show is the brainchild of artist and author Cynthia von Buhler, whose Italian immigrant grandfather, a speakeasy owner named Frank Spano, was shot and killed on a Manhattan street in 1935. Though the shooter was caught, his case was inexplicably dismissed, leaving the question of motive forever unanswered.  
---end game quote---  
source [http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/214593](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317111943/http:/www.brownpapertickets.com/event/214593 "http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/214593")

Perhaps this specimen is a prop?

Don

I did mention Courier as an answer to "what font would be the most similar to this font that is available to mac".  
Assuming that, in this case, as a prop, monospacing and colour (so, no Courier New) is more important that letter shape.  
Otherwise, the already mentioned by Don American Typewriter also comes with every installation of Mac OS X.

Don't be snarky, Don! ;-)  
Bardia asked the same two questions in another thread. There there was a single answer to both. Here you thoroughly answered (as usual) to the first and I tersely answered to the second.

On closer examination, I have formed the opinion that the image looks too authentic to have been whipped up as a prop for the Speakeasy Dollhouse game.  
Don

Don, I think it is a prop. No sig for the M.D. examiner...

Copy of a blank hospital form itself is probably ligit. Text easy to set in Ps ...faking an M.D.'s signature tho seems to push the prop a little bit further than they were willing to go.
